metadata.description: Synthetic interventional pulmonology procedure notes for airway dilation and cryotherapy procedures

airway_dilation_notes.note_text:
Patient: Thompson, Margaret A.
MRN: 3847291
DOB: 04/18/1956
Date: 12/05/2025
Facility: Memorial Regional Medical Center, Houston, TX
Physician: Dr. Elena Rodriguez, MD

PRE-OP DX: Post-intubation tracheal stenosis
POST-OP DX: Same, s/p dilation
PROCEDURE: Bronchoscopy with balloon dilation of tracheal stenosis

INDICATION: 68 y/o female with progressive dyspnea and stridor 6 weeks post extubation following prolonged ICU stay. CT showed subglottic stenosis with 70% narrowing.

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
Patient brought to OR, placed under general anesthesia with jet ventilation. Flexible bronchoscopy revealed circumferential web-like stenosis 2cm below vocal cords with 65-70% luminal obstruction. Sequential balloon dilation performed using CRE balloon dilator, starting at 10mm, progressed to 12mm, then 14mm over three cycles. Each inflation held for 60 seconds at 8 ATM. Post-dilation exam showed adequate lumen restored to approximately 90% patency. No mucosal tears. Minimal bleeding controlled with observation.

COMPLICATIONS: None
EBL: <5mL
DISPOSITION: PACU, planned same-day discharge

PLAN: Repeat bronchoscopy in 6-8 weeks. Discuss stent if recurrence. Proton pump inhibitor started.

Elena Rodriguez, MD
Interventional Pulmonology

code_rationales.31630: Bronchoscopy with tracheal/bronchial dilation (balloon method) for stenosis.

airway_dilation_notes.note_text:
Pt: Williams, Robert J.
MRN: 5928374
DOB: 11/22/1971
Date: 12/06/2025
Location: University Hospital, Denver, CO
MD: Dr. Michael Chen

Dx: RMS bronchus stenosis post lung transplant
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with rigid bronchoscopy and bronchial dilation

HISTORY: 53 y/o male 8 months post bilateral lung transplant with worsening dyspnea. Surveillance bronch showed 80% stenosis at right mainstem anastomosis.

PROCEDURE:
General anesthesia via ETT 8.0. Flexible bronch confirmed severe web-like stenosis at RMS anastomosis. Rigid bronchoscopy performed through laryngeal mask. Sequential dilation with rigid dilators (7mm, 9mm, 11mm). Final lumen approximately 12mm achieved. Mild mucosal edema post-dilation. No significant bleeding. Left system normal.

Assessment: Successful dilation of RMS anastomotic stenosis
Plan: Surveillance bronch in 4 weeks. May need stent if recurrent.

M. Chen, MD

code_rationales.31630: Bronchoscopy with bronchial dilation (rigid method) for anastomotic stenosis.

airway_dilation_notes.note_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Garcia, Maria L.
MRN: 6734829
DOB: 07/14/1948
Date of Procedure: 12/07/2025
Facility: Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, Los Angeles, CA
Attending: Dr. Sarah Kim, MD
Fellow: Dr. Jonathan Park, MD (PGY-6)

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Left mainstem bronchus stenosis secondary to granulation tissue post stent removal

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same

PROCEDURE: Bronchoscopy with balloon dilation of left mainstem bronchus

INDICATIONS: 76 y/o female with history of LMS silicone stent removed 3 months ago, now with recurrent dyspnea. CT chest shows 60% narrowing at prior stent site with granulation tissue.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia, ETT 7.5

FINDINGS AND PROCEDURE:
Flexible bronchoscopy performed. RMS and right bronchial tree patent. LMS with circumferential granulation tissue causing 55-60% obstruction starting 1cm from carina extending 1.5cm. Balloon dilation performed with 12mm x 40mm CRE balloon, 3 cycles at 6 ATM x 60 seconds each. Post-dilation patency approximately 85%. Small mucosal tear at 3 o'clock position, no active bleeding. Lingula and LLL bronchi patent.

COMPLICATIONS: Minor mucosal tear, self-limited
EBL: Minimal

DISPOSITION: Recovery, planned overnight observation

PLAN:
1. Chest X-ray post-procedure
2. Follow-up bronchoscopy in 6 weeks
3. Consider repeat stent placement if stenosis recurs

Sarah Kim, MD
Interventional Pulmonology

clinical_context.radiographic_findings: CT: 60% LMS narrowing with granulation tissue
clinical_context.prior_therapy: Prior LMS silicone stent (removed 3 months ago)

code_rationales.31630: Bronchoscopy with balloon dilation for granulation tissue stenosis.

airway_dilation_notes.note_text:
Name: Anderson, James T.
MRN: 8472910
DOB: 02/28/1965
Date: 12/08/2025
Location: Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN
Attending: Dr. David Miller, MD

PREOP DIAGNOSIS: Tracheal stenosis post tracheostomy
POSTOP DIAGNOSIS: Complex tracheal stenosis, post dilation

PROCEDURE: Rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical dilation and balloon dilation

CLINICAL HISTORY:
59 y/o male with history of traumatic brain injury requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation and tracheostomy 4 months ago. Tracheostomy decannulated 6 weeks ago. Progressive stridor and dyspnea on exertion. CT neck/chest shows 75% tracheal stenosis at stoma site.

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
General anesthesia with spontaneous ventilation through rigid bronchoscope. Larynx normal. Subglottic region patent. At level of prior tracheostomy site (approximately 3rd tracheal ring), complex stenosis noted with combination of granulation tissue and fibrous web causing 70-75% obstruction over 2cm segment. Initial mechanical dilation with rigid bronchoscope (size 8, then 9). Balloon dilation with 15mm diameter balloon x 3 inflations at 10 ATM. Final patency approximately 80%. Distal trachea and bilateral mainstem bronchi normal.

COMPLICATIONS: None
EBL: <10mL

IMPRESSION: Successful dilation of post-tracheostomy tracheal stenosis
PLAN: Repeat dilation in 4-6 weeks vs. T-tube vs. surgical reconstruction depending on recurrence. Pulmonary rehab referral.

D. Miller, MD

clinical_context.radiographic_findings: CT: 75% tracheal stenosis at stoma site

code_rationales.31630: Bronchoscopy with tracheal dilation (combined rigid and balloon) for complex stenosis.

airway_dilation_notes.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL BRONCHOSCOPY NOTE

Patient: Nguyen, Thi H.
MRN: 9283746
DOB: 09/05/1952
Date of Service: 12/09/2025
Facility: Stanford Medical Center, Palo Alto, CA
Primary Operator: Dr. Lisa Wang, MD
Fellow: Dr. Kevin O'Brien, MD (PGY-5)

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
1. Bronchus intermedius stenosis
2. History of RLL sleeve resection for carcinoid tumor

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same, s/p successful dilation

PROCEDURES PERFORMED:
1. Flexible bronchoscopy
2. Balloon dilation of bronchus intermedius

INDICATIONS: 72 y/o female with history of RLL sleeve resection 18 months ago, presenting with progressive dyspnea and recurrent right lower lobe pneumonias. CT demonstrates 70% stenosis at surgical anastomosis.

ANESTHESIA: Moderate sedation with midazolam 3mg and fentanyl 75mcg IV

PROCEDURE NARRATIVE:
Patient placed in supine position with standard monitoring. Flexible bronchoscope (Olympus BF-1TH190) introduced through right nare. Vocal cords normal mobility. Trachea and carina normal. LMS and left bronchial tree unremarkable. RMS patent. At bronchus intermedius, severe circumferential stenosis noted at anastomotic site with approximately 65-70% obstruction. Pinhole opening visualized. Sequential balloon dilation performed: 8mm x 20mm CRE balloon (2 inflations x 45 sec at 4 ATM), then 10mm x 20mm balloon (2 inflations x 60 sec at 6 ATM), finally 12mm balloon (1 inflation x 60 sec at 6 ATM). Post-dilation patency estimated at 80-85%. RLL basilar segments now visible and patent. Minimal bleeding, resolved spontaneously.

COMPLICATIONS: None
SPECIMENS: None
EBL: <5mL

IMPRESSION:
Successful balloon dilation of post-surgical anastomotic stenosis at bronchus intermedius

RECOMMENDATIONS:
1. Continue current antibiotics for recent pneumonia
2. Follow-up bronchoscopy in 8 weeks
3. Consider stent placement if recurrent stenosis

Lisa Wang, MD
Division of Interventional Pulmonology

clinical_context.radiographic_findings: CT: 70% stenosis at RLL sleeve anastomosis
clinical_context.prior_therapy: RLL sleeve resection for carcinoid (18 months ago)

code_rationales.31630: Bronchoscopy with balloon dilation for bronchus intermedius stenosis.

cryotherapy_notes.note_text:
Patient: Martinez, Carlos R.
MRN: 1029384
DOB: 05/17/1958
Date: 12/03/2025
Facility: MD Anderson Cancer Center, Houston, TX
Physician: Dr. James Wilson, MD

PRE-OP DX: Endobronchial squamous cell carcinoma, RUL with 80% obstruction
POST-OP DX: Same, s/p cryotherapy debulking

PROCEDURE: Rigid bronchoscopy with cryotherapy ablation

INDICATIONS: 66 y/o male with advanced squamous cell lung cancer, not a surgical candidate. Progressive dyspnea with near-complete RUL obstruction. Palliative debulking requested.

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
General anesthesia with rigid bronchoscope ventilation. Large exophytic tumor at RUL orifice causing 80% obstruction with extension into bronchus intermedius. Cryotherapy performed using Erbe Erbokryo CA unit with flexible cryoprobe. Multiple freeze-thaw cycles applied to tumor surface:
- RUL orifice: 4 cycles, 30 sec freeze each
- Bronchus intermedius tumor extension: 3 cycles, 30 sec each

Significant tumor necrosis achieved. Necrotic tissue debrided with rigid suction. Post-procedure patency improved to approximately 50% at RUL, BI now 80% patent. Moderate bleeding controlled with cold saline and topical epinephrine.

COMPLICATIONS: Moderate bleeding, controlled
EBL: ~75mL

IMPRESSION: Successful palliative cryotherapy debulking
PLAN: Repeat bronchoscopy in 1 week for additional debulking. Radiation oncology consult. Palliative care involved.

J. Wilson, MD

clinical_context.primary_indication: Endobronchial squamous cell carcinoma with CAO
clinical_context.radiographic_findings: CT: RUL mass with 80% endobronchial obstruction

code_rationales.31641: Bronchoscopy with destruction of tumor by cryotherapy; rigid access for ventilation/debridement included/bundled.

cryotherapy_notes.note_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Johnson, Patricia A.
MRN: 2847563
DOB: 03/22/1961
Date of Procedure: 12/04/2025
Facility: Cleveland Clinic, Cleveland, OH
Attending: Dr. Robert Chen, MD
Fellow: Dr. Amanda Foster, MD (PGY-6)

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Left mainstem endobronchial carcinoid tumor

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same, s/p cryotherapy

PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy with cryotherapy ablation of endobronchial tumor

INDICATIONS: 63 y/o female with incidentally discovered LMS carcinoid tumor on CT for unrelated workup. Biopsy confirmed typical carcinoid. Patient declines surgical resection. Endobronchial cryotherapy planned for tumor control.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia, ETT 7.5

PROCEDURE NARRATIVE:
Flexible bronchoscopy performed. Trachea and carina normal. RMS and right bronchial tree normal. LMS with polypoid tumor arising from posterior wall, 15mm in size, causing approximately 40% obstruction. Tumor has typical carcinoid appearance (pink, vascular). Cryotherapy performed using Erbe cryoprobe:
- 5 freeze-thaw cycles applied circumferentially to tumor base
- Each cycle: 20 seconds freeze, 10 seconds thaw
- Visible blanching and early necrosis noted

Post-procedure: Tumor appears devitalized. Lumen maintained. No significant bleeding.

COMPLICATIONS: None
SPECIMENS: None (prior biopsy diagnostic)
EBL: <5mL

IMPRESSION:
Successful cryotherapy ablation of LMS carcinoid tumor

PLAN:
1. Repeat bronchoscopy in 6 weeks to assess response
2. Consider additional cryotherapy sessions if residual tumor
3. Long-term surveillance with CT and bronchoscopy

Robert Chen, MD
Division of Pulmonary Medicine

code_rationales.31641: Bronchoscopy with destruction of tumor (carcinoid) by cryotherapy.

cryotherapy_notes.note_text:
Pt: Davis, William M.
MRN: 4738291
DOB: 08/14/1955
Date: 12/05/2025
Location: Northwestern Memorial Hospital, Chicago, IL
MD: Dr. Emily Thompson

Dx: Recurrent granulation tissue post RMS stent removal
Procedure: Bronchoscopy with cryotherapy for granulation tissue ablation

HISTORY: 69 y/o male s/p RMS silicone stent for malignant CAO (adenocarcinoma, now in remission). Stent removed 2 months ago. Surveillance bronch shows recurrent granulation tissue at prior stent margins causing 50% stenosis.

PROCEDURE:
Moderate sedation (propofol infusion). Flexible bronchoscopy via oral route. RMS with circumferential granulation tissue at 2cm from carina, 50% obstruction. LMS normal. Cryotherapy (spray cryotherapy, CSA Medical TrueFreeze) applied to granulation tissue:
- Anterior wall: 3 applications x 5 seconds each
- Posterior wall: 3 applications x 5 seconds each  
- Lateral walls: 2 applications each side x 5 seconds

Immediate tissue blanching and edema noted. Post-treatment lumen slightly improved. Expected further improvement with tissue sloughing over 1-2 weeks.

COMPLICATIONS: None
EBL: Minimal

PLAN: Repeat bronchoscopy in 2 weeks to assess response and debride necrotic tissue. Consider balloon dilation if stenosis persists.

E. Thompson, MD

clinical_context.radiographic_findings: Bronchoscopy: Granulation tissue at prior stent site

follow_up_plan: Consider balloon dilation if stenosis persists

code_rationales.31641: Bronchoscopy with destruction of granulation tissue using spray cryotherapy.

cryotherapy_notes.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE NOTE

Patient: Brown, Sandra K.
MRN: 5849271
DOB: 12/03/1949
Date of Service: 12/06/2025
Facility: UCSF Medical Center, San Francisco, CA
Attending: Dr. Michael Nakamura, MD
Fellow: Dr. Christina Lopez, MD (PGY-5)

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
1. Small cell lung cancer with endobronchial disease
2. Right upper lobe bronchus obstruction

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same, s/p palliative cryotherapy

PROCEDURES PERFORMED:
1. Rigid bronchoscopy
2. Cryotherapy ablation of endobronchial tumor
3. Mechanical debridement

CLINICAL HISTORY: 75 y/o female with extensive stage small cell lung cancer. Despite chemotherapy, progressive endobronchial disease causing RUL collapse and post-obstructive pneumonia. Palliative bronchoscopic intervention requested.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia with jet ventilation

FINDINGS:
Rigid bronchoscopy introduced. Trachea patent. Carina sharp. LMS and left bronchial tree normal. RMS with tumor extending from RUL orifice, completely occluding RUL takeoff and causing 60% narrowing of bronchus intermedius. Tumor is friable, necrotic centrally.

PROCEDURE:
1. Cryotherapy (Erbe Erbokryo) applied to tumor bulk:
   - RUL orifice: 6 freeze-thaw cycles (30 sec freeze/15 sec thaw)
   - BI extension: 4 cycles
2. Mechanical debridement using rigid suction and forceps
3. Tumor core extracted en bloc

RESULT: RUL orifice now 40% patent (was 0%). BI improved to 90% patency. Significant tumor burden removed. Active bleeding controlled with cold saline lavage.

COMPLICATIONS: Moderate bleeding (controlled)
EBL: 100mL

SPECIMENS: Tumor fragments sent to pathology

DISPOSITION: ICU overnight monitoring

PLAN:
1. Chest X-ray post-procedure
2. Continue IV antibiotics
3. Repeat bronchoscopy in 5-7 days
4. Oncology follow-up for additional chemotherapy

Michael Nakamura, MD
Interventional Pulmonology

clinical_context.primary_indication: Small cell lung cancer with endobronchial obstruction

code_rationales.31641: Bronchoscopy with destruction of tumor by cryotherapy; mechanical debridement bundled when same site.

cryotherapy_notes.note_text:
Patient: Lee, David H.
MRN: 6738492
DOB: 01/25/1963
Date: 12/08/2025
Facility: Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC
Physician: Dr. Jennifer Adams, MD

PREOP DIAGNOSIS: Tracheal papillomatosis
POSTOP DIAGNOSIS: Same, s/p cryotherapy ablation

PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy with cryotherapy ablation of tracheal papillomas

CLINICAL HISTORY:
61 y/o male with recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (RRP), HPV-related. Multiple prior procedures for laryngeal involvement. Now with tracheal extension. Progressive cough and mild dyspnea. CT shows multiple papillomas in mid-trachea.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia, LMA

FINDINGS AND PROCEDURE:
Flexible bronchoscopy through LMA. Larynx with minimal scarring from prior procedures, cords mobile. Subglottic region clear. Mid-trachea (4-6cm below cords) with multiple papillomatous lesions, largest 8mm, total of 6 lesions causing approximately 30% obstruction collectively.

Cryotherapy performed using flexible cryoprobe (Erbe):
- Each papilloma treated with 2-3 freeze-thaw cycles
- Freeze time 15-20 seconds per cycle
- Total of 15 applications

All visible lesions treated. Immediate blanching noted. No significant bleeding. Distal trachea and bronchial tree normal.

COMPLICATIONS: None
EBL: <5mL

IMPRESSION: Successful cryotherapy ablation of tracheal papillomas

PLAN:
1. Short course oral steroids for airway edema
2. Follow-up bronchoscopy in 8-12 weeks
3. Consider adjuvant cidofovir if rapid recurrence
4. ENT follow-up for laryngeal surveillance

Jennifer Adams, MD
Interventional Pulmonology

clinical_context.primary_indication: Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis with tracheal extension

code_rationales.31641: Bronchoscopy with destruction of tracheal papillomas by cryotherapy.

airway_dilation.cpt_description: Bronchoscopy with tracheal/bronchial dilation or closed reduction of fracture

cryotherapy.cpt_description: Bronchoscopy with destruction of tumor or relief of stenosis by any method
common_indications: Small cell lung cancer with CAO
